Hi Elliot, no offence, but do not try to confuse your sword with a Juyo 
or=
 higher sword unless yours is of the same level. The hamon running off 
the=
 kissaki IS a fatal flaw, make no bones about that. Swords with fatal 
flaw=
s that make Tokubetsu Hozon, Juyo or Yashu saku are swords of 
extraordinar=
y worth, and a flaw that is fatal can not take away it's 
history. These sw=
ords are typically famous because they are rare, or 
were carried by someon=
e important or famous. General swords, made by the 
not so famous sword smi=
ths, no matter how nice will most likely fail all 
attempts at kanteisho if=
 theirs is a fatal flaw like the hamon running 
off the Ha or Kissaki, a Ha=
giri and the likes.

We all learn hard lessons and we never like being told=
 that our hard 
earned and well spent money if for naught, but this is a mu=
gs game, it 
takes nerves of steel and a firm resolve. All I can suggest is=
 to get 
over it and move on. I mean that in the nicest possible way. I am =
not 
trying to be smart, just realistic.

Good luck

Richard Turner



Elli=
ott wrote:
>
> I was complaining about learning nothing from shinsa (NY 200=
6)other
> than a falling off temperline in the tip is (maybe) a fatal flaw.=

> Since I am definitly a 'newbee' and I study, study, study, I found
> som=
ething called YAKIOTOSHI. I also studyied the JUYO BIJUTSU HIN and
> TOKUBE=
TSU JUYO blades that have this wonderful feature. Yakiotoshi is
> of no con=
cern, infact an attribute to old, Koto swords.
>
> I am happier to find thi=
s out myself from studying than to have
> nothing told to me after a shinsa=
. What they could have said, "This is
> a Koto blade possibly made by Sukes=
ada but we won't paper it due to
> the temperline running off in the tip". =
Even without paper, thats
> money well spent.
